awd_titl_txt: The Quantum Atlas: A Visual Guide to an Unseen World
awd_abstract_narration:
As part of its overall strategy to enhance learning in informal environments, the Advancing Informal STEM Learning (AISL) program seeks to advance new approaches to, and evidence-based understanding of, the design and development of STEM learning in informal environments. This includes providing multiple pathways for broadening access to and engagement in STEM learning experiences, advancing innovative research on and assessment of STEM learning in informal environments, and developing understandings of deeper learning by participants. The goal of this project is to make 21st century quantum science comprehensible and engaging to non-expert informal adult learners. This project has strong potential to add new knowledge about the public's perception and understanding of quantum physics. This scientific content is often difficult for informal audiences to grasp, and there are relatively few accessible learning resources for a non- professional audience. The development of this online, interactive resource with short animations, graphics, and simulations has strong potential to fill this gap. It will develop a visually driven online resource to engage non-expert audiences in understanding the basics of quantum physics.  The web design will be modular, incorporating many multimedia elements and the structure will be flexible allowing for future expansion.  All content would be freely available for educational use. There is potential for extensive reach and use of the resources by informal adult learners online as well as learners in museums, science centers, and schools. Project partners are the Joint Quantum Institute at the University of Maryland and the National Institute of Standards and Technology, College Park.

An independent evaluation of the project will add new knowledge about informal learners' perceptions and/or knowledge about quantum science and technology.  An initial needs assessment via focus groups with the general public will be designed to find out more about what they already know about quantum physics topics and terminology, as well as what they want to know and what formats they prefer (games, simulations, podcasts, etc.).  In person user testing will be used with early versions of the project online resource using a structured think-aloud protocol.  Later in year 1 and 2, online focus groups with the general public will be conducted to learn what they find engaging and what they learned from the content.  Iterative feedback from participants during the formative stage will guide the development of the content and format of the online resources.  The Summative Evaluation will gather data using a retrospective post-survey embedded with a pop-up link on the Atlas followed by interviews with a subset of online users.  Google Analytics will be used to determine the breadth and depth of their online navigation, what resources they download, and what websites they visit afterward.   A post-only survey of undergraduate and graduate students who participated in resource development will focus on changes in students' confidence around their science communication skills and level of quantum physics understanding.

por.por_cntn:
The Quantum Atlas: A Visual Guide to an Unseen World project was a 3 year grant to demonstrate a feasible and accessible method for explaining quantum topics to informal learners online. The project team designed, built and evaluated a web application, which includes 17 multimedia glossary-like entries. This project was motivated by the lack of reputable, evaluated online resources aimed at introducing non-experts to quantum science. While there are substantial 20th century inventions arising from of this field of STEM, and projected 21st century societal impacts of the newer, related field of quantum information science, the public has little access to learning tools about quantum topics. The project included a set of surveys to gauge the public's engagement, interest, awareness and comfort learning quantum science. It also conducted dozens of interviews at the beginning and end of the project to inform the design and assess impact to target audiences. The primary deliverable at the end of the project funding (which included 2 extensions due to COVID-19 and team relocations) is a feature-rich website for exploring quantum physics and quantum information topics. Secondarily, the project evaluation data will contribute to the intellectual knowledge in the field of science communication. The project is primarily aimed at the non-expert adult public, but is also serving educators seeking to introduce this topic to K-12 and lower-division undergraduate students. 

Design of the Quantum Atlas

The Quantum Atlas team uses a lighthearted approach to conceptualizing quantum mechanics and its associated applications. This design was chosen primarily to break down perceptions of quantum physics as, for example, 'only for geniuses' or 'mystical.' The final design, validated by evaluation, originated from a team of science writers with expertise in physics, undergraduate students, and graduate students. The majority of students on the project design team had little or no background in physics and provided critical guidance on the approach. The resulting web application combines light-hearted text, cartoon images, interactive simulations, photos, audio clips, and animations/videos to explain quantum physics concepts. 

Evaluation

The project's evaluation included formative and summative assessments, with surveys and focus groups that bookended the project. In addition, there were assessments of the early version of the web application to guide iterative design and development. Most respondents and focus group participants provided positive feedback on the project content and design, and many report having learned concepts and/or becoming less intimidated by the topic through the Atlas web application. The surveys probed interest, awareness, and familiarity with physics and quantum topics among hundreds of respondents in both 2018 and 2021. 

Impact

The Quantum Atlas project fills a gap in information resources for the public around the topic of quantum science. The need for learning resources is further amplified by the global investments in this field of STEM, including the US National Quantum Initiative Act of 2018. According to limited website tracking analytics, the project currently has a growing user base, with ~1000 users per month (40% female/60%male),  90% of which are new to the site. Visitors typically view two entries and the most visited concepts are superposition, entanglement, quantum vs. classical, and quantum states. Currently, outside of this project's data, there is very little published information on public literacy and awareness around quantum-related science topics. The survey data collected in this project will be useful to guide further, more expansive data collection, product development, and research programs seeking to increase public literacy in the larger field of quantum information science and engineering. Due to the lack of gender diversity in physics, the project specifically oversampled a female population when conducting evaluation to ensure that the design did not inadvertently alienate or create barriers for women seeking out learning resources on quantum science. The project was also disseminated to groups that specifically promote equity and diversity in STEM.

Additionally, the project provided opportunities for approximately 15 students at different educational and career stages to learn science communication skills including writing, illustration, animation, audio, and video production. Upon graduation, many of the project's students entered into either careers in science communication, or attended graduate/professional school.

Sustainability

The project will be sustained beyond the initial funding by two host institutions: the University of Maryland and the University of Illinois Urbana-Champaign. The project continues to garner attention from other institutions, with guest contributions, and will be translated into Spanish.

Images (1 of )
  • Spin separates every particle in the universe into two categories, depending on whether their spin is an integer like 1 (bosons) or a half-integer like 1/2 (fermions). The cartoon is an example doodle from the Atlas.
    Eileen Stauffer
    Creative Commons
    Emily Edwards
    Cartoon of fermions and bosons
  • Laser cooling is a critical tool in technologies such as atomic clocks. At their nexus, criss-crossing lasers can bring atoms to a near standstill. This image is a snapshot of an interactive simulation of laser cooling from the Atlas
    Sean Kelley
    Creative Commons
    Emily Edwards
    Laser Cooling Simulation
  • Teleportation is a method for transmitting quantum information. The image is an example infographic from the Quantum Atlas.
    Shivani Mattikalli
    Creative Commons
    Emily Edwards
    Teleportation infographic with panels
  • The energy of an atom is an example of a quantized property: It's forced to live on a staircase of allowed values. This cartoon is an example doodle from the Quantum Atlas.
    Eileen Stauffer
    Creative Commons
    Emily Edwards
    cartoon of ramp and stairs for Quantum Atlas
  • Quantum states change by a different set of rules than classical states. For example, classical waves can't climb over a barrier that's too tall, but quantum waves can. This image is a screen shot of an animation from the Quantum Atlas
    Sean Kelley
    Creative Commons
    Emily Edwards
    Quantum tunneling
  • The diagnostic technique MRI depends on quantum physics and the concept of spin. The infographic explains this concept in the Atlas.
